content:

[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img] The system feels incomplete without Pluto..3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: Everything we believed was a LIIIEEEEEEE
content:
Thanks for the link, I was wondering about the outcome, but forgot to look it up.
Well, obviously that means I forgot the wondering part as well, but I digress.

Basically this whole "planet" definition is something we humans thought it.
I was thinking of an analogy-ish something, came up with size, but I think that is pretty much what this Pluto deal is about.
Who decides what is big, what is small?
Everyone does for themselves, based on the local environment; it's all pretty relative really.
In the end, "planet" is just a word, Pluto didn't really change; it's still the same thing.

Well, I'll go and actually read the article now, in case it's not just about size and my above point doesn't make as much sense anymore. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

content:
Good riddance! I never liked that little runt anyway.

Actually, the new definition seems pretty good to me, plus it keeps us from ever needing to add more planets to our charts (unless we're missing something really obvious). Pluto still gets to be a dwarf planet, which is pretty cool.________________

However it's not a big deal, like was pointed out it's just a word and words have no real meaning but the meaning we giver them ourselves. Nothing changes except for the language of scientist specialized in space and not may of us are part of them.

On the contrary; very much has cahnged. Pluto's status is not just a mere word; it has become ingrained into our culture and is a minor, but nonetheless tangible piece of our cultural identity. It will take time for the change to sink in, but something fundamental about how we view the universe has shifted.A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

However, now that Pluto is no longer a planet, this means that Scoripo now has no "ruling planet". HA HA HA! ASTROLOGY IS SO SCREWED!!!!! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

title: Re: Everything we believed was a LIIIEEEEEEE
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]In what way is Pluto involved in our cultural identity?

And blah, blah, blah, etc[hr][/quote]

There is a phenomenon known as popular science; it is made up of all those tiny things we were taught in school or on tv, and it has a disproportionate effect on our worldview. This includes things like newtons apple tree, that there are 7 colors in a rainbow [indigo was added to make it the lucky number 7] and that you'd explode in a vacum.

Until now pluto was viewed as a planet, a bit odd yes, indeed the oddball of the solar system, but a planet nonetheless. Now it is one among many bodies,a bit of solar derbis n the outside of the system. This has had an impact, otherwise why would there be all that media attention, something cherished that we learnt in our youth has been changed.

Now the focus has shifted to the kupier belt as a whole. Public perception of the solar system has been shifted. It will take a few years for it to be fully accepted, but eventually it should sink into the relm of popular science and impact the way we look at our local part of space. It may not be as influential as say the discovery of an anticancer drug, but it'll have more awareness.
Szevvy Forever!
And Spleen never!

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/rcwn.jpg[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: Re: Everything we believed was a LIIIEEEEEEE
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]There is a phenomenon known as popular science; and another hope nonsense[hr][/quote]
Since when is popular science equal to 'our cultural identity'?
Again I see no involvement whatsoever but perhaps you have another tactic to avoid the question?

[quote]Quote:[hr]second paragraph: more nonsense and 'This has had an impact, otherwise why would there be all that media attention, something cherished that we learnt in our youth has been changed.'[hr][/quote]
There is an impact because it's 'news', wait till the storm is gone and see how bit your impact is.

[quote]Quote:[hr]This has had an impact, otherwise why would there be all that media attention, something cherished that we learnt in our youth has been changed.[hr][/quote]

[quote]Quote:[hr]but eventually it should sink into the relm of popular science and impact the way we look at our local part of space.[hr][/quote]

And what will the difference will it make for the new look of popular science? A teacher that tells children that pluto is a dwarf planet, or just forgets about it? Wow, big deal.
